The Cuckmere River is rising in Alfriston, following Thursday's rain. Flood impacts will continue to affect North Street, River Lane, The Old Clergy House, Deans Place Hotel, Alfriston. In Hellingly, river levels have now peaked, but remain high. Flooding will continue to affect fields, roads, and gardens of properties on Mill Lane, Station Road, Church Lane and Church Road, Hellingly. Only isolated showers are forecast Friday and Saturday. River levels should begin to fall by 17:00 09/01/2025 in Alfriston, and will continue to fall in Hellingly. River levels should return nearer to a normal level by Saturday evening. However, further rain is forecast Sunday which could cause minor flood impacts to return to all Cuckmere communities. We are closely monitoring the situation. Avoid roads that flood (Mill Lane and Church Road Hellingly, North Street Alfriston). This message will be updated by 13:00 10/01/2026.

High river levels are expected to cause flooding on Friday. 
Flooding is expected on 09 January 2026 from 14:00, as a lot of rain fell in Storm Goretti (35mm). 
Flooding will affect fields, rural roads, gardens, and properties including The Old Clergy House, Deans Place Hotel, and properties near North Street, Willows Car Park and River Lane, Alfriston. Access along Litlington Road may be restricted by flood water. Only a small amount of rain is forecast Friday and Saturday. River levels and flood risk should begin to reduce in Alfriston by 17:00 09/01/2026, but will not return to nearer to a normal level until Saturday evening. Another 10-20mm of rain is forecast on Sunday 11/01/2026, which could cause some minor flood impacts to return. 
We are closely monitoring the situation .

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the West of Dorset
items.message: High groundwater levels may lead to flooding. Flooding is possible in the West Dorset area. Groundwater levels are high in response to heavy rainfall earlier in December. Levels are slowly falling but remain high, and flooding of fields and roads is still possible. No significant rainfall is forecast for the next few days. Where groundwater is near the surface, intense rainfall will lead to surface water flooding. We are closely monitoring the situation. Residents are advised to prepare property resilience measures and ensure that pumps are working where they have been installed. This message will be updated by 4:00PM on 13th January 2026 or as the situation changes.

High river levels today may lead to flooding. Flooding is possible on 9th January 2026.  We expect the river to remain high throughout the next few days and flooding to gardens, driveways or external garages is possible close to the river. 
Our forecasts indicate that flooding to properties isn't likely and therefore flood warnings are not expected to be issued. We are closely monitoring the situation.  Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. Avoid low lying roads, near rivers which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 19:00 on 10th January 2026 or as the situation changes. "

items.description: River Great Ouse from Thornborough to Newport Pagnell
items.message:
Areas most at risk are those around the River Great Ouse from Thornborough to Newport Pagnell, including Dogsmouth Brook. Flooding is possible this evening and overnight 09 and 10 January 2026 as a result of heavy rainfall from Storm Goretti. We are not expecting the situation to escalate, or to issue any further warning messages at this time.
We are monitoring rainfall and river levels.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses. Monitor local water levels and weather conditions and don’t put yourself or others at risk.
This message will be updated by 10:00 on Saturday 10th January 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding for the South Winterbourne Valley
items.message: High groundwater levels are still expected to cause flooding. Flooding is still expected from 6th January 2026 onwards. Groundwater levels in West Dorset remain high. Areas that could be affected include: Winterbourne Abbas, Winterbourne Steepleton, Martinstown, Winterbourne Monkton, Winterbourne Herringston and Winterbourne Came. The groundwater level at the Kingston Russell borehole has fallen to 116.68m, and is expected to fall further over the next few days. Residents may experience inundation of septic tanks and sewer systems. Properties may experience flooding in cellars in affected areas. Flooding of roads is expected. Roads may be damaged by floodwater. Any intense rainfall will lead to surface water flooding. We are closely monitoring the situation. If you have a pump, make sure it is working and switched on. Think about alternative power sources in case of power cuts. This message will be updated by 3:00PM on 13th January 2026, or as the situation changes.

items.description: North Sea at Scarborough - North Bay
items.message:
High tides, strong winds and large waves are expected to cause flooding today. 
Flooding is expected from 21:00 on 09/01/2026 to 00:30 on 10/01/2026. 
Large waves over the next two days may lead to flooding. This is due to Storm Goretti. Locations most affected will be coastal roads and footpaths. 
We are closely monitoring the situation . 
Avoid coastal roads, footpaths and carparks, which may be flooded . 
This message will be updated by 8:30AM on 10 January 2026 or as the situation changes.

There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain.

Strong winds and large waves on Friday has led to minor flooding. Minor flooding is possible for 2 hours either side of Friday afternoon's tide at 15:15 on 09/01/2026. The shingle beach has been impacted by high energy waves from Storm Goretti. The weather increases tide table values by 0.1 m. The total forecast tide is 6.48 metres Chart Datum (2.83 mAOD) at Eastbourne. Strong North Westerly Force 7 wind. Beach top properties along Pevensey Bay are likely to be affected by spray generated by the strong winds and large waves. Saturday's tide at 03:30 10/01/2026 is forecast to be 9 cm lower (2.74 mAOD). Tides will continue to fall and flood risk should reduce. We are closely monitoring the situation at low tide we will check and maintain the condition of Pevensey beach. Don't put yourself or others at risk. Danger - stormy seas. Avoid Pevensey beach and Herbrand Walk at high tide. This message will be updated by 06:00 PM on 10/01/2026.

items.description: The Thorpeness Hundred River and the River Ore
items.message:
High river levels today may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible on 09 January 2026 . River levels are high following heavy rainfall overnight. 
Areas most at risk are low lying roads and riverside areas around Knodishall and Coldfair Green on the Hundred River, and around Brook Lane and Fairfield Road in Framlingham on the River Ore. We are not expecting the situation to escalate, or to issue any further warning messages at this time. 
We are monitoring rainfall and river levels . 
Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water . 
This message will be updated by 10:00AM on 10 January 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Beult from Bethersden and Pluckley to Stile Bridge
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message:
River levels remain high and flooding is expected. 

Flooding is expected from the afternoon of 09 January 2026 and will continue overnight to 10 January 2026. 

Flooding of property is possible, particularly around Bethersden and Smarden 

We are monitoring rainfall and river levels . 

Start acting on your flood plan if you have one and deploy any flood protection measures you may have. 

This message will be updated by 11:00AM on 10 January 2026 or as the situation changes.
